HEAD.title: Pennsylvania Spatial Data Access | Full Metadata

BODY.H2: Delaware River Basin Catchments Based on Strahler Stream Order 1 from National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) Stream Centerline Features for 8-digit HUC

DL.DD: Delaware River Basin Catchments Based on Strahler Stream Order 1 from National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) Stream Centerline Features for 8-digit HUC

DIV.PRE: A breakthrough in water resources management occurred in 1961 when President Kennedy and the governors of Delaware, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and New York for the first time signed concurrent compact legislation into law creating a regional body with the force of law to oversee a unified approach to managing a river system without regard to political boundaries. The members of this regional body - the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) - include the four basin state governors and the Division Engineer, North Atlantic Division, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, who serves as the federal representative. Commission programs include water quality protection, water supply allocation, regulatory review (permitting), water conservation initiatives, watershed planning, drought management, flood loss reduction, and recreation. Much of the new drilling interest taking place in northeastern Pennsylvania and southern New York is targeted at reaching the natural gas found in the Marcellus Shale formation, which underlies about 36 percent of the Delaware River Basin. Because the Marcellus Shale is considered a tight geologic formation, natural gas deposits were not previously thought to be practically and economically mineable using traditional techniques. New horizontal drilling and extraction methods, coupled with higher energy costs, have given energy companies reason to take a new interest in mining the natural gas deposits within the Marcellus Shale. In connection with natural gas drilling, the commission has identified three major areas of concern: 1.Gas drilling projects in the Marcellus Shale or other formations may have a substantial effect on the water resources of the basin by reducing the flow in streams and/or aquifers used to supply the significant amounts of fresh water needed in the natural gas mining process. 2.On-site drilling operations may potentially add, discharge or cause the release of pollutants into the ground water or surface water. 3.The recovered "frac water" must be treated and disposed of properly. DRBC is identifying methods, geospatial data, and other information to support decision making on how best to oversee the Marcellus Shale drilling in the Delaware River Basin (DRB).

In 2012, catchments were generated in the Delaware River Basin for 8-digit HUCs in areas underlain by the Marcellus Shale (all of 02040101, 02040102, 02040103, 02040104; and headwater areas of 02040106 and 02040203) based on the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) Strahler first- and second-order streams. At that time, the remaining 8-digit HUCs were not included. The completion of HUCs 02040106 and 02040203, along with HUCs 02040105, 02040201, 02040202, 02040205, 02040206, and 02040207 were part of this current project.

Geospatial datasets attributed with detailed stream-order and catchment-area data form the foundation needed to identify High Value Water Resources (HVWR). Using the datasets, DRBC will be better informed as they develop protective natural gas regulations within the basin and identify HVWR areas. This scope of work is consistent with USGS federal goals of advancing the knowledge of regional hydrologic systems and processes, providing scientific technical support to regional basin commissions, and water-resources data and information for use by multiple parties for planning and operational purposes. This dataset is designed to act as a planning tool to see where surface-water runoff may flow. The dataset is not a definative source and therefore should not be used for legal purposes. Site-specific, higher-resolution data should be collected to determine actual flowpaths of surface-water runoff.
publication date

DL.DD: Environment as of Metadata Creation: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.4.1 (Build 5686) Service Pack N/A (Build N/A)

DIV.PRE: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted. Attributes are accurate as coded.
No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.
Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.
This catchment dataset is accurate at the 1:24,000 scale National Map Accuaracy Standards, acceptable deviation, for this scale is 40 feet, or 12.2 meters.
A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.
Generate nodes using NODEPOINT and buffer resulting nodes by 35 meters,

National Hydrologic Dataset (NHD) centerline-flow data from PA StreamStats used as source for Strahler stream order processing. Command-line ArcInfo was needed to run Strahler.aml. Center-line flow data was edited for consistency to remove straggler lines from braided streams. Strahler processing reference: Fast algorithm for automatically computing Strahler stream order, 1990, Lanfear, Kenneth J. water Resources Bulletin, 26: 977-981.

Select By Attributes to get Strahler order 1 and 2 nodes: "strahler = 1 and FID_endpts = -1" for Strahler Order 1 "strahler = 2 and FID_endpts = -1" for Strahler Order 2. Extract Strahler 1 and 2 values and create independent shapefiles.
Snap the nodes to a 900-cell defined, flow accumulation raster using Spatial Analyst Tools -> Hydrology -> Snap To Pour Point, snap distance of 20 meters. Use Watershed Tool to delineate catchments.
Visually verify generated watershed are correct. Edit node locations to remove single-cell catchment definition, bad snapping, and poor catchment areas. Rerun watershed delineation tool.
Add AreaSqm, AreaAcres, and NEW_ID attributes in the feature attribute table.
Write metadata
Send dataset out for review. Respond to reviewer comments. Edit and correct data and metadata, as necessary. Make data available to the public.

DL.DD: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

DIV.PRE: Generated by ArcGIS software through a raster to vector conversion.
ArcGIS
Generated by ArcGIS software through a raster to vector conversion.
ArcGIS
Area calculated in square miles by using the 'Calculate Geometry' option in feature attribute table. An alias field name has been generated: AreaSqMiles, to differentiate between meters and miles.
ArcGIS
Area calculated in acres by using the 'Calculate Geometry' option in feature attribute table.
ArcGIS

A unique identification number for catchments generated from a stream (str) centerline feature from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD). The "Field Calculator" option was used in the feature attribute table to combine 'str', the Strahler Stream Order number, and the GRIDCODE field. An alias field has been created to reflect the source used to generate these catchments: StreamBased_ID. The 'NEW" part of the field name was used as a project term to help separate the manual gap processing (mgp) catchments with the newer (new) catchment generation since there was catchment processing in 2012 for areas underlain by the Marcellus Shale based on the NHD and these catchments could be interpreted as older processing.
USGS

During a Select By Location analysis, a canal value of "0", is defined as the catchment did not intersect with a canal feature from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD). During a Select By Location analysis, a canal value of "1", is defined as the catchment did intersect with a canal feature from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and the canal may impact the catchment.
Producer defined

During a Select By Location analysis, an LPR value of "0", is defined as the catchment did not intersect with a a lake, pond, or reservoir feature from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD). During a Select By Location analysis, an LPR value of "1", is defined as the catchment did intersect with a lake, pond, or reservoir feature from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and the lake, pond, or reservoir may impact the catchment.
Producer defined

The entity and attribute information provided here describes the tabular data associated with the data set. Please review the detailed descriptions that are provided (the individual attribute descriptions) for information on the values that appear as fields/table entries of the data set.

The entity and attribute information was generated by the individual and/or agency identified as the originator of the data set. Please review the rest of the metadata record for additional details and information.
215 Limekiln Road
